com.lonepulse.robozombie.util
Class Assert

java.lang.Object
  com.lonepulse.robozombie.util.Assert

public final class Assert
extends Object

A collection of utility services which eases certain trivial validations.

Note that while most of the services are generic, some assertions may be coupled to certain modules. For example, the exceptions which are thrown due to assertion failures may not be a good fit for all scenarios. Consult the documentation for further information.

Since:
1.3.0

Version:
1.1.0

Author:
Lahiru Sahan Jayasinghe

Method Detail

assertAssignable

public static <T> T assertAssignable(Object arg,
                                     Class<T> type)

Asserts that the given Object is assignable to the specified type. If either the generic Object or the Class is null a NullPointerException will be thrown with the message, "The supplied argument was found to be <null>". If the object was not found to be in conformance with the specified type, a ClassCastException will be thrown with the message, "The instance of type <argument-type> cannot be assigned to a <specified-type>".

Parameters:
arg - the argument to be asserted for type conformance

type - the Class type to which the argument must conform

Returns:
the argument which was asserted to conform to the specified type

Throws:
ClassCastException - if the supplied argument does not conform to the specified type

Since:
1.3.0

assertNotNull

public static <T> T assertNotNull(T arg)

Asserts that the given argument is not null. If the argument is null a NullPointerException will be thrown with the message, "The supplied argument was found to be <null>".

Parameters:
arg - the argument to be asserted as being not null

Returns:
the argument which was asserted to be not null

Throws:
NullPointerException - if the supplied argument was found to be null

Since:
1.3.0

assertNotNull

public static <T> T assertNotNull(T arg,
                                  String message)

Asserts that the given argument is not null. If the argument is null a NullPointerException will be thrown with the provided message.

Parameters:
arg - the argument to be asserted as being not null

arg - the message to be provided with the NullPointerException if the assertion fails

Returns:
the argument which was asserted to be not null

Throws:
NullPointerException - if the supplied argument was found to be null

Since:
1.3.0

assertNotNull

public static <T> T assertNotNull(T arg,
                                  Class<T> type)

Asserts that the given argument is not null. If the argument is null a NullPointerException will be thrown with the message, "The supplied <type> was found to be <null>".

Parameters:
arg - the argument to be asserted as being not null

type - the Class of the argument to be asserted

Returns:
the argument which was asserted to be not null

Throws:
NullPointerException - if the supplied argument was found to be null

Since:
1.3.0

assertNotEmpty

public static <T> T assertNotEmpty(T arg)

Asserts that the given argument is neither null nor empty. The null check is performed using assertNotNull(Object). If the argument is empty a NullPointerException will be thrown with the message, "The supplied argument was found to be <empty>".

Note that only the following types are accepted: CharSequence, Collection, Map, Object[], boolean[], char[], byte[], short[], int[], long[], float[], double[]. All other types will manage to pass this assertion (granted the argument is not null).

Parameters:
arg - the argument to be asserted as being not empty

Returns:
the argument which was asserted to be not empty

Throws:
NullPointerException - if the supplied argument was found to be null

IllegalArgumentException - if the supplied argument was found to be empty

Since:
1.3.0

assertLength

public static <T> T assertLength(T arg,
                                 long length,
                                 long... optional)

Asserts that the given argument is not null and has the specified number of elements. The null check is performed using assertNotNull(Object). If the argument does not contain the specified number of elements IllegalArgumentException will be thrown with the message, "The supplied argument did not contain the required number of elements".

Note that only the following types are accepted: CharSequence, Collection, Map, Object[], boolean[], char[], byte[], short[], int[], long[], float[], double[]. All other types will manage to pass this assertion (granted the argument is not null).

Parameters:
arg - the argument to be asserted as being not empty

length - the acceptable number of required elements
optional - any optional lengths which might be acceptable

Returns:
the argument which was asserted to be of the required length

Throws:
NullPointerException - if the supplied argument was found to be null

IllegalArgumentException - if the supplied argument did not contain the required number of arguments

Since:
1.3.0

assertValid

public static <T> T assertValid(T context,
                                Validator<T> validator)

Asserts that the given context is valid using the supplied Validator along with a few other trivial validations such as a null check.

Parameters:
context - the context to be validated using the given Validator

validator - the Validator to be used on the given context

Returns:
the given context which was asserted to be valid

Since:
1.3.0
